acronyms.description: 2G refers to the second-generation of cellular network technology, which introduced digital transmission, improved voice quality, and support for services like SMS (Short Message Service) [[1]]. It succeeded 1G and was first deployed globally in the early 1990s [[2]].
3G represents the third generation of mobile telecommunications technology, offering faster data transfer speeds and enabling advanced services such as video calling and mobile internet access.

3GPP is a collaboration between groups of telecommunications associations responsible for developing protocols for mobile telecommunications, including GSM, UMTS, LTE, and 5G NR [[3GPP.org]](https://www.3gpp.org/about-3gpp/about-3gpp).
A 3GPP Change Request (CR) is a formal document submitted to propose modifications or enhancements to existing 3GPP technical specifications [[3GPP TS 21.101]](https://www.3gpp.org/specifications).

3GPP Technical Specifications (TS) define the standardized technical requirements and procedures for mobile communication systems, including radio interfaces, core networks, and service capabilities [[3GPP.org]](https://www.3gpp.org/specifications).

4G refers to the fourth generation of wireless communication technology, providing high-speed internet access and supporting advanced mobile broadband services such as streaming and VoIP [[ITUT]](https://www.itu.int/rec/T-REC-I.211-199308-I).

5G is the fifth generation of mobile network technology, designed to deliver significantly faster data rates, lower latency, and greater connectivity density compared to previous generations [[GSMA]](https://www.gsma.com/5g/what-is-5g/).

The 5G Core (5GC) is the central network architecture component of 5G systems, responsible for managing user authentication, session management, mobility, and traffic routing in cloud-native and virtualized environments [[3GPP TS 23.501]](https://www.3gpp.org/specifications/204-specification-groups-work-items/specifications-and-ts/1983-ts-23-501).

Abstraction and Control of TE Networks
acronyms.description: Virtualised Network
Middle East - Asia - Pacific

acronyms.definition: Access Network Discovery and Selection Policy

acronyms.description: A set of rules and protocols that allows different software applications to communicate with each other
a system that combines batteries with other electrical components to provide a reliable and efficient source of power.
interdomain routing protocol designed to provide loop-free routing between organizations.

acronyms.definition: Customized Applications for Mobile network Enhanced Logic
acronyms.description: a set of standards designed to work on either a GSM core network or the UMTS network by extending the services offered within a GSM network. Provides the mechanisms to support operator specific services, which are not covered by standardized GSM services
FlexGrid

acronyms.definition: European Conference of Postal and Telecommunications Administrations

acronyms.description: It's a type of attack that tricks the victim into submitting a malicious request. Django provides built-in protection against CSRF attacks through the {% csrf_token %} template tag and the ensure_csrf_cookie() decorator. This ensures that only authenticated requests are processed, protecting user data and system integrity.
Centralized database storing subscriber information and profiles in telecommunications networks
Network node that handles user plane mobility and acts as gateway between radio and core network
Component that manages control plane functions in the SGSN architecture
Style sheet language used for describing the presentation of HTML documents
Instance of a communication service in network slice management
Reference signals used in 4G/5G systems for channel quality measurement and beamforming
Function responsible for translating communication service requirements to network slice requirements

acronyms.definition: Cisco Secure Client Diagnostics and Reporting Tool

acronyms.description: DevOps is a transformative methodology integrating software development and IT operations, emphasizing automation, collaboration, and rapid feedback.

In telecommunications, DL refers to the transmission path from a network base station or satellite to the user device, often used in mobile networks like LTE and 5G to define data transfer directionality.
DNN is a parameter used in 5G networks to identify a specific Data Network within the operator's infrastructure, enabling the selection of the appropriate packet data network for connectivity.
DNS is a server that responds to queries by translating domain names into IP addresses, facilitating access to web services and resources over the internet.

DNS is a hierarchical decentralized naming system for computers, services, or other resources connected to the Internet or a private network, primarily used to translate human-readable hostnames into numerical IP addresses.

DO refers to a functional component in network orchestration responsible for managing and coordinating workflows across individual domains, ensuring alignment with service-level agreements and policies in virtualized or cloud-native environments.

indicates the percentage of the battery that has been discharged relative to the overall capacity of the battery. Depth of Discharge is defined as the capacity that is discharged from a fully charged battery, divided by battery nominal capacity.

acronyms.definition: Data Over Cable Service Interface Specification

acronyms.description: the buying and selling of goods and services, or the transmitting of funds or data, over an electronic network, primarily the internet
A large AI model trained on broad data that can be adapted for various downstream tasks, serving as a foundation for other AI models
A cloud computing model that allows running individual functions in response to events without managing infrastructure
Software that is freely available for anyone to use, modify, and distribute
A data structure and processing method where the first element added is the first one to be removed
A computational model used to design systems that can be in exactly one of a finite number of states at any given time
A measure of computer performance, especially relevant in AI/ML computations and model training

acronyms.definition: Fault, Configuration, Accounting, Performance and Security

acronyms.description: a system of interactive visual components for computer software that displays objects which convey information and represent actions that can be taken by the user.

devices which can only transmit in one direction at one time. Although data can move in two directions, it cannot be at the same time. Both devices can transmit and receiving but when one device is sending, the other is receiving

A framework of policies and technologies for ensuring that the proper people in an enterprise have the appropriate access to technology resources. It handles the authentication, authorization, and management of user identities within IT systems.

acronyms.definition: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers

acronyms.description: IODT refers to the process of verifying that different devices and systems can work together seamlessly, exchanging data and performing functions as intended across varied platforms and vendors.

An IOM is a hardware or software component responsible for handling input and output operations in a computing or control system, facilitating communication between the system and external devices or networks.
IoT refers to the network of interconnected physical devices embedded with sensors, software, and connectivity capabilities that enable them to collect, exchange, and act on data autonomously
Fundamental protocol for relaying packets across network boundaries in computer networks, providing addressing and routing functionality for communication over the internet.
Legal rights that protect creations of the mind such as patents, trademarks, and copyrights, granting the creator exclusive rights to use and distribute their intellectual assets.
Company that provides internet access services to customers
Internet Protocol implementation in the OSI network model layer 3
Administration and monitoring of IP address space within a network
Routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data using path labels rather than long network addresses
Protocol suite for securing Internet Protocol communications through authentication and encryption
Gateway that enables SMS delivery over IP networks in telecommunications systems
a circuit-switched telephone network system that transmits both data and voice over a digital line
The collaborative efforts between two or more organizations aimed at developing new products, services, or processes through shared resources and expertise
A lightweight data interchange format that is easy for humans to read and write and easy for machines to parse and generate
A software metric used to measure the size of a computer program by counting the number of lines in the text of the program's source code. Used for estimating programming productivity or effort.

moves the computing of traffic and services from a centralized cloud to the edge of the network and closer to the customer. Instead of sending all data to a cloud for processing, the network edge analyses, processes, and stores the data.
A field of artificial intelligence focused on building systems that can learn from and make decisions based on data.
A protocol used by IPv6 routers to discover multicast listeners on a directly attached link, part of the ICMPv6 suite.
An extension to the Label Distribution Protocol (LDP) for setting up point-to-multipoint (P2MP) and multipoint-to-multipoint (MP2MP) Label Switched Paths (LSPs) for multicast traffic.
A key control node in the LTE Evolved Packet Core (EPC) responsible for idle mode UE tracking, paging procedures, and bearer activation/deactivation processes.
An advanced Multiple Input Multiple Output (MIMO) technology using a large number of antennas (e.g., dozens or hundreds) at the base station to improve spectral efficiency, capacity, and coverage.
Refers to the spectrum band between 30 GHz and 300 GHz. Used in 5G NR for providing high data rates and capacity, typically over shorter distances due to higher propagation loss.
A service that enables mobile phone users to retain their mobile telephone number when changing from one mobile network carrier to another.
Activities related to keeping network equipment, software, and services operational, including troubleshooting, repairs, updates, and technical assistance.
A network sharing configuration where multiple core network operators connect to a shared Radio Access Network (RAN).
A specific instance of a Managed Object Class within a network management model (e.g., in TMN or 3GPP management frameworks), representing a manageable network resource.
A detailed, step-by-step document outlining the actions required to perform a specific network task, change, or maintenance activity safely and correctly.
A network sharing configuration where multiple operators share the same Radio Access Network (RAN) infrastructure.
a virtual banking system, money transfer, payments and micro-financing service that provides transaction services through a SIM card.
A routing technique in telecommunications networks that directs data using short path labels rather than long network addresses, avoiding complex lookups in a routing table.
A profile of MPLS designed specifically for transport networks, providing carrier-grade OAM (Operations, Administration, and Maintenance) and protection switching capabilities similar to SDH/SONET.
A dedicated cellular network tailored for a specific enterprise or organization, providing enhanced security, control, performance, and coverage for specific business needs.
A lightweight, publish/subscribe network protocol that transports messages between devices. Ideal for constrained devices and low-bandwidth, high-latency networks, commonly used in IoT.
A receiver diversity technique where signals from multiple antennas are weighted and combined to maximize the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) of the resultant signal.
A component in the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) architecture that provides media-related functions such as conferencing, transcoding, media announcements, and interactive voice response (IVR).
The server component (control plane) of a Mobile Switching Center (MSC) in GSM/UMTS networks, responsible for call control, mobility management, and supplementary services for circuit-switched calls.
A protocol used between multicast routers, specifically Rendezvous Points (RPs) in different PIM-SM domains, to share information about active multicast sources.
Part of the International Mobile Subscriber Identity (IMSI), uniquely identifying a mobile subscription within the home Public Land Mobile Network (PLMN).

acronyms.definition: Mobile Station International Subscriber Directory Number
acronyms.description: The globally unique phone number allocated to a mobile subscriber, used for routing calls and messages to the subscriber.
A network element acting as a proxy server that handles multiple services or protocols, often used for mediation or interworking.
Refers to a call, message (e.g., SMS), or data session that originates from the network and terminates at the mobile device (User Equipment).
A version of a new product which allows a team to collect the maximum amount of validated learning about customers with the least effort.
An application server within the IP Multimedia Subsystem (IMS) architecture that provides supplementary services for multimedia telephony, such as call waiting, call forwarding, and conferencing.
A measure of the predicted elapsed time between inherent failures of a mechanical or electronic system during normal system operation. Represents reliability.
A basic measure of the maintainability of repairable items. It represents the average time required to repair a failed component or device.
A concept referring to seamless user experiences and service continuity across multiple devices (e.g., phone, tablet, PC) and potentially multiple user identities or profiles.
Allows a base station (e.g., Wi-Fi AP or cellular base station) to communicate with multiple user devices simultaneously using the same time and frequency resources through spatial multiplexing.

acronyms.definition: Mandatory Use-case requirements for SDN for Transport
acronyms.description: An IETF draft defining mandatory functional requirements for applying Software-Defined Networking (SDN) principles to transport networks.
The self-service mobile application provided by Vodacom for its customers to manage their accounts, services, and usage.
Value-Added Services delivered over mobile networks, beyond standard voice calls and SMS, such as ringback tones, mobile money, location-based services, etc.
Electromagnetic waves in the frequency range of 300 MHz to 300 GHz, commonly used for point-to-point communication links in telecommunications backhaul and fixed wireless access.

A business and technology model where network capabilities (e.g., bandwidth on demand, location services, security functions) are exposed as programmable services via APIs for internal or external developers.
acronyms.tags: api, programmability, business-model, sdn, network-slicing, automation

acronyms.description: an interface that allows the component to communicate with a higher-level component, using the latter component's southbound interface. The languages or protocols commonly used include SNMP and TL1.

Organization for the Advancement of Structured Information Standards

acronyms.description: a small operating system, pre-installed as firmware on bare metal network switches, that provides an environment for automated operating system provisioning
equipment that use optical fibers to transmit data signals. They are used in a variety of applications, including long-distance transmission, metropolitan area networks (MANs), and access networks.
Challenge-Handshake Authentication Protocol

a device that computes paths on behalf of the nodes in the network. It can be a router, a COTS server, part of the OSS, or a virtualized entity running in a cloud. When a network node needs a path for an LSP, it makes a request to the PCE using the PCE protocol (PCEP). The PCE has access to topology information for the entire network and uses this in path computations.
a special set of rules that allows a Path Computation Client (PCC) to request path computations from Path Computation Elements (PCEs)
PWAs combine the flexibility of the web with the experience of a native application, allowing users to install web apps to their home screen, receive push notifications, and work offline
A demonstration of a solution's business value and ROI, typically following a PoC
A cloud computing model where a third-party provider delivers hardware and software tools for application development
A networking technology that translates multiple local ports to a single public IP address
Information that is delivered as a unit between peer entities of a network
A family of multicast routing protocols for IP networks that provide one-to-many and many-to-many distribution
Highest level on aggregation network hierarchy, connects to the core network.
Intermediate aggregation level between POC1 and POC3, sometimes aggregates Cell Sites directly. Normally connected to POC1 in ring architectures or slightly meshed, always with optical fibre.
First aggregation point in the hierarchy after last mile/access

PTP, standardized as IEEE 1588, is crucial for achieving sub-microsecond synchronization across networked systems. Recent studies highlight its vulnerabilities to internal attacks, prompting the development of security enhancements like Trusted Supervisor Nodes (TSNs) to bolster its resilience.

Modern PTT services have evolved beyond traditional walkie-talkie functionality, integrating with LTE and VoIP technologies to provide robust communication solutions in various scenarios, including emergency response and disaster relief.

In the context of machine translation, QE refers to the automatic prediction of translation quality without reference translations. Recent approaches employ multi-task learning and pre-trained language models to enhance the accuracy of QE systems.

The QnQ model integrates both the quality and quantity of user contributions to assess trustworthiness in participatory sensing applications. This dual-faceted approach aims to mitigate the impact of malicious or low-quality data submissions.

QoE encompasses the overall user satisfaction with a service, influenced by factors like network performance and content delivery. Advanced models now utilize machine learning to predict QoE, enabling proactive optimization of user experiences.
acronyms.tags: user experience, multimedia services, machine learning

acronyms.definition: Quad Small Form-factor Pluggable Dual Density

acronyms.description: a fixed radio transceiver that provides wireless communication coverage to a specific geographic area

part of the digital microwave transmission system. It supports a point-to-point digital fixed radio service and long-haul wireless transmission system. The RFU works together with the Indoor Unit (IDU) to provide multiple types of service interfaces.
Traffic Engineering

SDC, particularly in medical device networks, leverages IEEE 11073 standards and Time-Sensitive Networking (TSN) to enable semantic interoperability and real-time communication, facilitating automatic configuration and ensuring safety-critical operations.

SDDC abstracts and virtualizes all data center resources, including compute, storage, and networking, allowing for centralized management and automation, thus enhancing scalability and operational efficiency.
acronyms.tags: virtualization, data center, automation, cloud infrastructure

acronyms.description: SDH is a standardized protocol for transmitting large volumes of data over optical fiber networks, offering high-speed, synchronized data transfer and facilitating efficient multiplexing of digital signals.

An SDK is a collection of software tools and libraries that developers use to create applications for specific platforms, providing APIs, documentation, and debugging tools to streamline development processes.
SDL enhances mobile network capacity by utilizing unpaired spectrum for downlink transmission, improving data throughput and user experience, especially in data-intensive applications.

SDN decouples the control plane from the data plane in networking equipment, enabling centralized control, programmability, and dynamic management of network resources, thus fostering innovation and flexibility.

SD-WAN applies SDN principles to WAN connections, allowing for intelligent routing, improved performance, and centralized management across multiple network paths, enhancing connectivity for distributed enterprises.
acronyms.tags: WAN optimization, network management, enterprise connectivity

acronyms.description: SeGW provides secure communication in mobile networks by handling authentication, encryption, and authorization processes, ensuring data integrity and protecting against unauthorized access.

acronyms.definition: Security and Privacy by Design Assurance

acronyms.description: SR simplifies network operations by encoding paths as sequences of segments, enabling scalable and flexible traffic engineering. Recent studies focus on SR's integration with MPLS and IPv6, highlighting its benefits in reducing protocol overhead and enhancing network programmability.

SR technology has advanced with deep learning models, enabling more accurate and robust transcription of spoken language. Research emphasizes the use of large-scale datasets and neural networks to improve recognition in diverse and noisy environments.
acronyms.tags: AI, deep learning, NLP, audio processing

acronyms.description: SR OS is a network operating system designed for high-performance IP routing. It supports advanced features like segment routing and integrates with various network management protocols to enhance scalability and reliability.
acronyms.tags: network OS, IP routing, segment routing, scalability

acronyms.description: Single Root I/O Virtualization (SR-IOV) allows multiple virtual machines to share a single physical network interface card, improving I/O efficiency and reducing latency. Research explores its applications in cloud computing and data center environments.
acronyms.tags: virtualization, I/O efficiency, cloud computing, data centers

acronyms.description: Sounding Reference Signals (SRS) are used in wireless communication systems to estimate uplink channel conditions. Studies focus on optimizing SRS allocation to enhance channel state information accuracy, crucial for technologies like massive MIMO.
acronyms.tags: wireless communication, channel estimation, massive MIMO, 5G

acronyms.description: SR-TE combines segment routing with traffic engineering principles to optimize network resource utilization. Research highlights its ability to provide efficient path computation and fast reroute capabilities.
acronyms.tags: network optimization, path computation, fast reroute, MPLS

acronyms.description: SRVCC enables seamless handover of voice calls from LTE to legacy networks. Research discusses its implementation challenges and solutions to maintain call quality during transitions.
acronyms.tags: voice call continuity, LTE, network handover, IMS

acronyms.description: SS7 is a set of protocols used for exchanging information in public switched telephone networks. Recent studies address its security vulnerabilities and propose measures to protect against potential threats.
acronyms.tags: telecommunication protocols, PSTN, network security, signaling

acronyms.description: SSBs are used in 5G networks for cell search and initial access procedures. Research focuses on their design and role in beamforming to improve coverage and capacity in high-frequency bands.

acronyms.definition: Signalling Connection Control Part User Adaptation Layer

acronyms.description: connection-oriented transport protocol used over IP to ensure reliable transmission of packets
A strategy-level document that defines the tasks and duties required of a project contractor, and highlights project background and objectives at high level.

acronyms.definition: Topology and Orchestration Specification for Cloud Applications

acronyms.description: Interface traffic is carried through the radio frequency in the air. Data is compressed for efficient transmission of data. Original data of 64 KBPS on interface side is compressed to 13 KBPS on the air. The compression is done by TCSM.
A system that combines and analyzes customer data from multiple sources to provide comprehensive customer insights
A centralized system for managing digital certificates and PKI infrastructure across an organization

acronyms.definition: User Data Interworking, Coexistence and Migration

acronyms.description: A platform for managing and coordinating event-driven communications across distributed systems
A security approach that enables organizations to manage and secure all endpoints (mobile, desktop, IoT) from a single platform
A storage system that provides a unified view of multiple file systems and storage resources
IPv6 address type intended for local communications within a site or organization
Technology enabling seamless roaming between cellular and Wi-Fi networks
System for analyzing user behavior patterns and profile data to derive actionable insights
Centralized storage and management system for security and access control policies
Comprehensive security approach combining multiple security technologies and protocols

Enables broadband connectivity in remote areas, supporting IoT deployments and critical operations in sectors like energy and maritime. Recent studies highlight its role in bridging the digital divide and facilitating real-time data transmission where terrestrial infrastructure is lacking.
acronyms.tags: satellite communication, remote connectivity, IoT, broadband

acronyms.description: Consolidates multiple physical switches into a single logical entity, enhancing network redundancy and simplifying management. Research emphasizes its benefits in reducing downtime and improving network resilience.

An enhancement of the traditional Spanning Tree Protocol, allowing for per-VLAN spanning tree instances. Studies demonstrate its effectiveness in optimizing network performance by preventing loops and improving convergence times in complex VLAN environments.
acronyms.tags: network protocols, VLAN, loop prevention, convergence

acronyms.description: Establishes a unified framework for technology deployment across Vodafone's global operations, streamlining processes and accelerating the adoption of emerging technologies like 5G and IoT.
A regulatory approach that allows alternative operators to access incumbent networks at a virtual level, facilitating competition in broadband services and promoting market entry and innovation.
acronyms.tags: telecom regulation, broadband access, market competition, network sharing

acronyms.description: A telecommunications network that extends over a large geographical area for primary purpose of computer networking
A third-generation (3G) mobile telecommunications technology that supports high-speed data transmission
A wireless computer network that links two or more devices using wireless communication to form a local area network within a limited area
A security protocol developed for wireless networks to address vulnerabilities found in earlier protocols
A network of distributed autonomous devices that use sensors to monitor physical or environmental conditions
An AI model trained on vast amounts of text data to understand and generate human-like language.
A type of large language model developed by OpenAI, known for its strong text generation capabilities.
An AI technique that combines a retrieval system (to find relevant information) with a generative model (to create an answer).
A field of AI focused on enabling computers to understand, interpret, and generate human language.
A subfield of NLP focused on machine reading comprehension and understanding the meaning of text.
A subfield of NLP focused on producing natural language text from structured data or computational representations.
A deep learning model architecture introduced in 'Attention Is All You Need', heavily used in NLP and other sequence tasks.
A language representation model developed by Google, known for its effectiveness in various NLP tasks.
A type of generative model that learns a probabilistic mapping from input data to a latent space.
A class of generative models that learn to reverse a gradual noising process to generate data, often used for image generation.
The process of adapting a pre-trained model (like an LLM) to a specific task or dataset by training it further on relevant data.
The practice of designing and refining input prompts to guide generative AI models towards desired outputs.
The ability of a model to perform a task it hasn't been explicitly trained on, often by understanding instructions in the prompt.
The ability of a model to learn a new task from only a small number of examples provided in the prompt.
A high-level, interpreted programming language known for its readability and versatility in web development, data analysis, AI, and more
A set of 17 global goals established by the United Nations in 2015, aimed at addressing global challenges such as poverty, inequality, climate change, and environmental degradation by 2030.
An optical networking technology that increases bandwidth by transmitting multiple data channels over a single fiber-optic cable using different light wavelengths.
An open standard that enables AI systems to connect and interact with external tools, data sources, and services through a standardized interface.
An iterative optimization algorithm used to minimize a function by updating parameters in the opposite direction of the gradient of the function with respect to the parameters.
A supervised machine learning algorithm used for classification and regression tasks by finding the optimal hyperplane that separates data into classes.
A type of machine learning where an agent learns to make decisions by performing actions and receiving feedback in the form of rewards or penalties.
